person.persName: John Alexander McClernand (Illinois politician and soldier.)

body.p: Springfield, Illinois, politician and soldier. Breckinridge County, Kentucky, native. Son of John McClernand and Fatima Seaton Cummins McClernand. Married to Sarah F. Dunlap McClernand in November 1843. Father of Hellen C. McClernand, Edward J. McClernand, Fatima C. McClernand, John McClernand, and Sarah McClernand. Married to Minerva Dunlap McClernand on December 23, 1862. Father of Rosalind McCernand. Served as a private in the Illinois State Militia during the Blackhawk War of 1832. Attorney in Shawneetown, Illinois, in 1835. Editor of the Shawneetown Democrat in Shawneetown in 1835. Member of the Illinois House of Representatives in 1836, 1840, 1842, and 1843. Member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Illinois, from 1843 to 1851, and from 1859 to1861. Resident of Jacksonville, Florida in 1851. Resident of Springfield, Illinois, in 1856. Attorney and politician in Springfield in 1860. Employed James Lawles as a coachman in Springfield in 1860. Employed Leonard Lawles, M. J. Tellestin, and Charlotte Sims as servants in Springfield in 1860. Appointed Brigadier General of Volunteers (U.S.A.) on May 17, 1861. Promoted to Major General of Volunteers on March 21, 1862. Commanded Union Army's XIII Corps in 1863 and 1864. Resigned from military service on November 30, 1864.
